May 23, 1999: Fiction
STAR WARS: Episode I -- The Phantom Menace, by Terry Brooks.
(Lucas/Ballantine, $25.) How it all began for Anakin Skywalker (a k a Darth
Vader).
WE'LL MEET AGAIN, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) Did a
woman murder her husband?
WHITE OLEANDER, by Janet Fitch. (Little, Brown, $24.) The ordeals of growing
up as experienced by a teen-age girl whose single mother murders a lover.
THE GIRL WHO LOVED TOM GORDON, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $16.95.) A
young girl who is a fan of the Boston Red Sox gets lost in the woods.
A NEW SONG, by Jan Karon. (Viking, $24.95.) A clergyman and his wife move
600 miles from home.
BITTERSWEET, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) A woman copes with a
midlife crisis.
THE TESTAMENT, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) A reclusive billionaire,
a burned-out lawyer and a missionary are brought together by a startling secret.
EAST OF THE MOUNTAINS, by David Guterson. (Harcourt Brace, $25.) A man
with cancer returns to the eastern Washington of his youth to commit suicide.
JOINING, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $24.) In 13th-century England, a woman
gradually changes her feelings about her partner in an arranged marriage.
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $16.95.) A British boy finds his fortune attending a school of
witchcraft.
TARA ROAD, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $24.95.) Two women exchange
houses for the summer.
THE HOURS, by Michael Cunningham. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) The lives
of two modern women converge with the life and work of Virginia Woolf.
EYE OF THE BEHOLDER, by Jayne Ann Krentz. (Pocket, $24.) An Art Deco
expert becomes involved with a rich businessman who detests her stepfather.
VITTORIO, THE VAMPIRE, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $19.95.) A supernatural siren
seduces a teen-age boy.
CRYPTONOMICON, by Neal Stephenson. (Avon, $27.50.) From World War II to
the World Wide Web: a tale of code making and code breaking.
Non-Fiction
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The
lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War
II.
YESTERDAY, I CRIED, by Iyanla Vanzant. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) A counselor
describes how she turned painful experiences into feelings of hope.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A sportswriter
tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
BELLA TUSCANY, by Frances Mayes. (Broadway, $25.) Remembering a spring
and summer spent in Italy.
ALL TOO HUMAN, by George Stephanopoulos. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) The
former adviser to President Clinton recalls his years in the White House.
THE CENTURY, by Peter Jennings and Todd Brewster. (Doubleday, $60.) An
account of the 20th century.
THE MAJORS, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $25.) A journalist reports on
1998's major golf tournaments.
COMFORT FROM A COUNTRY QUILT, by Reba McEntire. (Bantam, $19.95.)
The country music star tells how she balances the demands of career and family.
THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead,
$22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.
THE LEXUS AND THE OLIVE TREE, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus &
Giroux, $27.50.) A journalist explains the instant electronic global economy.
BLACK HAWK DOWN, by Mark Bowden. (Atlantic Monthly, $24.) The bloody
battle between American forces and Somali street fighters in Mogadishu in 1993.
WE ARE OUR MOTHERS' DAUGHTERS, by Cokie Roberts. (Morrow, $19.95.)
The television news anchor's personal reflections on women.
BUSINESS @ THE SPEED OF THOUGHT, by Bill Gates with Collins Hemingway.
(Warner, $30.) How new technology is changing the ways business is done.
TRAVELING MERCIES, by Anne Lamott. (Pantheon, $23.) A chronicle of the
author's journey toward faith.
CONVERSATIONS WITH GOD: Book 1, by Neale Donald Walsch. (Putnam,
$19.95.) The author addresses questions of good and evil, guilt and sin.
WOMAN, by Natalie Angier. (Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $25.) A reporter examines
